title: @meddler @riot can we have a context for the skarner nerf?
body:
It just seems out of the blue to hit him this hard. As is, i could see why you would nerf him slightly, looking at his stats. but keyword here: slightly, and not what seems like a humongous nerf. it really feels like something you'd have dropped on him during pre-hotfix juggernaut patch given its magnitude. so, just asking... why nerf him this hard?

For those unaware, the nerfs are as follows
Crystal Spires (Passive) Attack speed bonus lowered to [39-90%] from [43-160%]
Impale (R) total AD ratio down to .4 from 1

replies.body:
From what I understand, the team just wanted to try out a few different avenues as to how we want to nerf Skarner. Though it won't show up on the PBE over the holiday weekend, I believe the plan is to go with a pared down version of these nerfs for final changes.

It seems worth noting here that it can be difficult to really try more than one thing out at a time in an effort to land on the correct change when it comes to nerfs and buffs, because we tend to get large reactions from players when we do so. I'm not saying that reaction isn't justified (since we don't have the greatest history of being fully transparent on every change you see on the PBE), but I do think that's what is going on in this case.

why nerf him in the first place? I mean - he´s a snowbally champ thanks to the shrine-mechanic (control the map->control the shrines->not many places for your opponents to fight Skarner, just snowball with drakes and baron as they have to go through shrine-areas to get there) and currently lol is a snowbally environment so he does fairly well. But once you guys fix the game he´ll be back to a mostly useless creature that gets destroyed by adc-dmg before ever getting to a target he´d like to grab.

(on a sidenote...you guys still know that Ryze sits ~60%winrate for experienced players - or are u just keen on selling SKT-Faker-Ryze-Skins sometime soon?)

thats not fuly true, one might think scarner is very snowball due mapcontroll+shrines, but he needs time to scale up and becomes a monster mid lategame, haveing the hardest spike once E is maxed and 40% cdr are aquired, as it allows E-ult-E for 4sec total cc with a heavy displace, or E, pop stun on 3 different targets, E again.

Also, his kidnapping power is more powerfull later on once deathtimers and teamdps are higher, as catching one guy will often translate into multiple objectives come to lategame.

Nerfing skarner honestly is ok, they just have to be carefully on how they nerf him. I think the ult nerf on it's own would be already fine, 70% less as on his passive would be overkill and feel horrible on scarner, and any nerfs to his Q dps also would hit the worng spot imo.

And ryze needs some attention more than ever....
Um,you forgot to explain WHY Skarner should be nerfed in the 1st place.

We think he's too strong. Incredibly overpowered? No. But slightly too strong, hence going with a small set of nerfs. You're free to disagree with that assessment; that was my first reaction too. That said, this is a character that is around a 54% win rate, with an experienced player win rate that appears to easily break 60%, so it's not unreasonable to assess him as overtuned.

Skarner does have a low play rate, so yes, he can probably be balanced resting north of a 50% win rate. These changes aren't intended to (nor do I believe they will) be an enormous power hit, just a small power trim.

First of all, you could hardly call a nerf to his ultimate "taking a dump on him," so please don't blow things out of proportion.

As to trying to address a low play rate, there is an assumption here that we would like him to be a popular champion, or at least more popular than he is now. It's unlikely that Skarner will ever be popular, given the theme, fantasy, and kit of the character. His theme and fantasy aren't bad, just niche. And his kit just doesn't really have the best gameplay built into it, and it never really has. Keep in mind, when I mention good gameplay, I don't mean that the kit has never been and will never be fun; it's more that his moment-to-moment power has always been very stat checky. We'd have a lot of work to wholly fix that, and though we tried to chip at it with the Juggernauts update, it would be disingenuous of me to say that it was fixed. He's now more strategically interesting insofar as he thinks about and tries to set up where he fights you, but it's still not particularly interesting _how_ he fights you when he does.

For what it's worth, this isn't an isolated Skarner case. It's pretty consistent with many of the melee guys out there, especially the ones that we made 3-4 years ago.
How about the assumption that he should be enjoyable for his original playerbase? I quit him after the rework and refuse to touch him. He feels absolutely awful outside his ridiculous spire zones.
Sorry you don't enjoy him anymore.
What was the point of the rework in the first place? He fit his supposed juggernaut fantasy better before.

This could be me not remembering correctly, but I was under the impression both Brand and DFT were getting nerfs on the PBE.

Hey man thanks for taking the time to explain these changes to us, especially on thanksgiving, means a lot ^^

If you get the chance tho, could you take a hot minute to enlighten me on the thought process behind the hecarim nerfs, the passive and E changes specifically? Why are they being done and what you hope they accomplish? 

Thanks again friend

I don't have any deep insight into the particular Hecarim changes on the PBE, but I imagine it has to do with Hecarim's perma unit collision avoidance being somewhat fundamentally flawed given the kit he has. He just gets near you and then spams circles of damage onto you. If he is stronger and you don't have a tool to get away, he will win.

On the one hand, yes, he's always been this way, so the need for this particular change on this very patch is probably no greater than on any other patch. On the other hand, if he's deemed too powerful at the moment by the balance team (which seems to be the case), it seems like a good place to trim power.

For what it's worth, permanently ignoring unit collision is probably not something we should just put on champion kits, and I wouldn't really be opposed to us taking this from Fizz and Kassadin as well, even if it meant we had to compensate them with power elsewhere. It's just not that exciting for how powerful it is. I don't think anyone selects any of these champions primarily because they are excited about ignoring unit collision. As any of these champions, I'd rather have just about any of my spells be a bit stronger rather than always avoiding unit collision.

Even if someone was picking these champions solely for these reasons, this to me is more an argument that pathing/collision should be more tolerable on average than having players choose champions that ignore the rule.

Why not just remove unit collision in general? It's an archaic, unhealthy mechanic that, as you just said, adds unnoticed and exceptional power to champions who can ignore it. Seems to me like it just shouldn't be around if it's so powerful while being so unnoticed.

I'm not really the guy to make that call, but I will say I'd prefer that we do that over having champions that selectively ignore it on a case by case basis.

Unit collision between champions is actually something I do think is good, and I do think it's nice that my minions may cause small reroutes for enemies that are ahead of me, so unit collision isn't all bad. However, I do understand how frustrating and inconsistent it has felt on Live lately, and that's not ideal either.

Can you float the idea of minion unit collision removal as a boot upgrade, that seems to be the small type of added power that belongs as a boot upgrade available to everyone and choosing over the other ones.

>Yasuo is likely too strong, though it's hard to say by how much. Honestly, and I don't expect this to be a popular opinion, he's probably just more frustrating than he is actually overpowered.

so well, if he´s not too strong but still frustrating - he needs a rework.

Maybe. It depends how frustrating a champion should be. I think there's an argument to be made that if a champion isn't frustrating in one way or another, it's probably not very compelling/unique/interesting, though of course that isn't to say we should intentionally make frustrating champions.

Some champions can be frustrating and yet not complained as much because there are moments when you can decide to overcome it

Like Blitzcrank into Morgana for example. Morgana can make it very hard for Blitzcrank to do much, but there are still ways of baiting her spell shield, counting cooldowns or aiming for the person not spell shielded

I think the major complaint people have is that Yasuo decides the pace of his lane, whether or not you get to trade with him is in his capacity

i.e he has good disengage and engage. Champions that seem similar to him are either early game bullies or kill reliant {{champion:92}} {{champion:58}} 

But yasuo also scales hard with just farm which is why many people feel hopeless when forced to lane against him

Yeah, Yasuo feels great to play because he often has so much agency over how his lane goes. Unfortunately, that often seems to come at the expense of his opponents' agency, so it may be fair to say that's what's so frustrating about him.

That is an interesting thought. By "agency" you mean control over how the lane turns out: As in if he outplays his opponent(s), he has much more direct impact on the lane than a different champion?

Do you think that being 100% in control of how a lane turns out depending on how well you play is a good thing, or even possible? On one hand, it makes the game more skillful and gives direct control over the game to the player in question, and is great for competitive, but on the other hand you have to be careful because if the game is too skillful then it stops being fun and has a very high barrier of entry for new players.

> By "agency" you mean control over how the lane turns out: As in if he outplays his opponent(s), he has much more direct impact on the lane than a different champion?

Basically, yes. It's about how much control someone has over their fate. If a character is 100% in control of how a lane goes if played well, then that implies it doesn't even matter what their opponent does to defeat them, and it sucks to be that opponent and know that I can play as well as I want and it doesn't even matter all that much.

It's just a barrier based on how well the person can play their champion. These champions are commonly ones that people claim are overloaded. Yasuo, Lee Sin, Nidalee (to use a champion that I was responsible for) have all been guilty of this, and this is some of why we see them needing to be balanced around lower than 50% win rates; because when you actually play things perfectly on champions like these, you leave little room for your opponent to do much of anything.

Unfortunately, these champions are also commonly very popular because they have that feeling of being able to do anything with them, so it does someone beg the question of whether we should be trying to make more champions like that (that players feel like they are in full control of their destiny), or ones with clearer weaknesses for opponents to exploit (at the expense of some of that control).

Here's a hint:

The person playing the champion is outnumbered by the number of people playing against the champion. 1<5.
Wouldn't the fact that you're conflicted about this potentially imply that such champions based around these factors have no place in the game?

Not quite. There is a balance to be struck between the fun of the player and the fun of the opponent. I think it is possible to get the balance right and hence for these champions to have some place in the game.
The problem being that with {{champion:157}} particularly, that fun is clearly balanced towards Yasuo rather than towards Equilibrium.
That seems like it could be reasonably argued, yes.
That fact does not lead to that conclusion, no.

OK........ why?
Or are you just going to say: "no it doesnt" and leave?

He could be both!

Maybe Skarner is more overpowered than Yasuo, but Yasuo's overpoweredness is obvious (lifestealing constantly in fights, dashing everywhere, 100% crit after 1 1/2 items), and Skarner's is less so (just kinda overpowering you.)

EDIT: And yes, both Brand and DFT are getting nerfed. Brand's mostly getting a lovetap, though, just a mana cost increase on his pillar. Riot's probably wanting to see how the DFT changes for DoT champions affect him before doing anything more extreme.)

Hmm...
So will you end up nerfing his spires or chip off some excess power in other areas?
I'm all for the latter to be honest since a champion should excel in certain areas and fall shorter in others.
His ultimate for example's got a 200% total ad ratio, which isn't even necessary for how powerful of an abduction tool it is.

But his spires, oh boy, this is an aspect of Skarner that should be kept powerful. It's a similar window of power like Darius' Noxian Might and Garen's villain mechanic.

We still think the spires should be important to his success, but there's also an argument to be made for him having too many eggs in one basket, so to speak. For now, I believe we're sticking with the ult AD ratio and leaving the spire strength intact.

Phew, seems I can put my pitchforks away.

Still, I hope you understand why there was so much outrage due to the nerfs to seemingly unpopular champions.
The common notion seems to be that unpopular=Underpowered but it's often not the case.
Malzahar is a perfect example for this as was pre-rework Mordekaiser.

Still, It's good to see some of the thought process behind those changes, helps understand why you seemingly nerf things out of the blue and cease the rioting. (Hue)

Hell in the champion spotlight scarizard says it stops at the first champion hit, you guys did something.

Hi, thanks for the post.

> You don't really listen to the PBE, so what data are these changes gathering?

I get that it may feel this way, but it's not really true. Skarner and Graves are examples of where we didn't tune back given PBE feedback, and they came back too strong. However, there are also cases like Kog'Maw (where PBE people said he would be broken, we nerfed him a little bit, and he came out too weak), so it can be hit or miss.

There's also quite a bit to be gathered just from players' reaction to changes on sites like Surrender@20 or Reddit. At the end of the day we will sometimes (and maybe more often than not) have some unpopular decisions to make, but it's hardly because we don't care about people's opinions. It's a matter of balancing that perspective against what we think is right for the game state.

> I get that it may feel this way, but it's not really true. Skarner and Graves are examples of where we didn't tune back given PBE feedback, and they came back too strong. However, there are also cases like Kog'Maw (where PBE people said he would be broken, we nerfed him a little bit, and he came out too weak), so it can be hit or miss.

On the subject of kogmaw I actually don't think he came out too weak. Its just that the environment of having shorter games is not conducive to the success of a late game hyper carry. Once the snowballing and short game issues are addressed hes going to come back into his own even if you had left him alone.

I think that's taking it too far. Yeah, he's hurt a good deal by the shorter games, but his performance dropped way more than that of any other hypercarry in the game, and he wasn't even winning half of the games that actually did go really late. At some point, we have to conclude that he really is just weak and needs some help irrespective of the game environment.
